meta.title: Cystic Diseases of Kidney ADPKD & ARPKD

questions.text: Polycystic liver disease associated with ADPKD is different from autosomal dominant polycystic liver disease (ADPLD) by?

options.label: A
options.text: Caused by mutations in at least two distinct genes (PRKCSH and SEC63)

options.label: B
options.text: Does not progress to renal failure

options.label: C
options.text: Massive polycystic liver disease occurs almost exclusively in women with ADPKD particularly those with multiple pregnancies

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Polycystic liver disease associated with ADPKD is different from autosomal dominant polycystic liver disease (ADPLD), which is caused by mutations in at least two distinct genes (PRKCSH and SEC63 ) and does not progress to renal failure.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B: Polycystic liver disease associated with ADPKD is different from autosomal dominant polycystic liver disease (ADPLD), which is caused by mutations in at least two distinct genes (PRKCSH and SEC63) and does not progress to renal failure. Option: C: Massive polycystic liver disease occurs almost exclusively in women with ADPKD, particularly those with multiple pregnancies.

questions.text: A 38-year male is at risk for ADPKD and undergoes radiological imaging. Which of the following criteria is needed for diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Presence of at least two renal cysts (unilateral or bilateral)

options.label: B
options.text: Presence of at least two cysts in each kidney

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of at least four cysts in each kidney

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

questions.correct_answer: B. Presence of at least two cysts in each kidney
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Presence of at least two cysts in each kidney The presence of at least two cysts in each kidney is required for the diagnosis among at-risk subjects aged 30–59 years with a sensitivity value of 100% and specificity value of 100%.

Highyeild:

USG-based diagnosis.Modified Ravinsons criteria 15-29 years- >=3 cysts , unilateral/bilateral 30-59 years >=2 cysts in each kidney >=60 years >=4 cysts in each kidney Ultrasound Criteria for the Diagnosis of ADPKD Age (years) Criteria PPV NPV Original Ravine's PKD1 Diagnostic Criteria 15-29 ≥2 cysts, unilateral or bilateral 99 88 30-39 ≥2 cysts in each kidney 100 88 40-59 ≥2 cysts in each kidney 100 95 ≥ 60 ≥4 cysts in each kidney 100 100 Revised Unified Diagnostic Criteria 15-29 ≥3 cysts, unilateral or bilateral 100 86 30-39 ≥3 cysts, unilateral or bilateral 100 86 40-59 ≥2 cysts in each kidney 100 95 ≥ 60 ≥4 cysts in each kidney 100 100 Revised Criteria for Exclusion of Diagnosis 15-29 ≥1 cyst 97 91 30-39 ≥1 cyst 94 98 40-59 ≥2 cyst 97 100 ≥ 60 ≥3 cysts in each kidney 100 100

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A: The presence of at least two renal cysts (unilateral or bilateral) is sufficient for diagnosis among at-risk subjects between 15 and 29 years of age with a sensitivity value of 96% and a specificity value of 100%. Option: C: The presence of at least two cysts in each kidney and at least four cysts in each kidney, respectively, are required for the diagnosis among at-risk subjects aged 30–59 years and aged ≥60 years with a sensitivity value of 100% and specificity value of 100%.

questions.text: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is an inherited condition that causes small fluid-filled sacs called cysts to develop in the kidneys. All of the following are TRUE about the treatment of ADPKD EXCEPT?

options.label: A
options.text: No specific treatment to prevent cyst growth or the decline of renal function

options.label: B
options.text: Blood pressure control to a target of 140/90 mmHg is recommended

options.label: C
options.text: Lipid-soluble antibiotics against common gram-negative enteric organisms are likely to be less effective

options.label: D
options.text: Peritoneal dialysis may not be suitable for some patients with massively enlarged polycystic kidneys

questions.correct_answer: C. Lipid-soluble antibiotics against common gram-negative enteric organisms are likely to be less effective
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lipid-soluble antibiotics against common gram-negative enteric organisms are likely to be less effective Lipid-soluble antibiotics against common gram-negative enteric organisms include trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, quinolones, and chloramphenicol, and are preferred for cyst infection because most renal cysts are not connected to glomerular filtration and antibiotics that are capable to penetrate the cyst walls are likely to be more effective.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A: No specific treatment to prevent cyst growth or the decline of renal function has been approved by the S. Food and Drug Administration. Option: B: Blood pressure control to a target of 140/90 mmHg is recommended according to the guidelines from the eighth report of the Joint National Committee on Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Treatment of High Blood Pressure (JNC VIII report) for reducing cardiovascular complications in ADPKD and renal disease progression. Option: D: Peritoneal dialysis may not be suitable for some patients with massively enlarged polycystic kidneys due to the small intraabdominal space for an efficient peritoneal exchange of fluid and solutes and increased chance of abdominal hernia and back pain.

Extraedge:

Renal Manifestations of Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease Functional Manifestations Concentrating defect Reduced renal blood flow Hypertension → Target Organ Damage Cardiac Cerebrovascular Arteriolosclerosis and glomerulosclerosis Peripheral vascular disease Pain, Caused by Cyst hemorrhage Gross hematuria Nephrolithiasis Infection Renal enlargement Renal Failure, Possibly Caused by Interstitial inflammation Apoptosis of tubular epithelial cells Hypertensive glomerulosclerosis Compression atrophy

questions.text: ARPKD is caused by a DNA mutation (abnormality) in a gene called PKHD1, which produces a protein called fibrocystin that gives the kidney its structure. The faulty PKHD1 gene is responsible for small fluid-filled sacs (cysts) and scarring developing in the kidneys. Which of the following is NOT true about Classic ARPKD?

options.label: A
options.text: Generally diagnosed in utero or within the neonatal period

options.label: B
options.text: May be associated with polyhydramnios

options.label: C
options.text: May be associated with pulmonary hypoplasia

options.label: D
options.text: About 30% of affected neonates die shortly after birth due to respiratory insufficiency

questions.correct_answer: B. May be associated with polyhydramnios
questions.explanation:
Solution:

May be associated with polyhydramnios Reduced fetal urine production may contribute to oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia.

Highyeild:

PKD1 –On chromosome 16p known as polycystin-1(85%) PKD2 -on chromosome 4q known as polycystin 2(16%) PKD3 known as polycystin 3 GNAB gene mutation Better prognosis PKD2>PKD1

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A: Classic ARPKD is generally diagnosed in utero or within the neonatal period, and characterized by greatly enlarged echogenic kidneys in diseased fetuses. Option: C: Reduced fetal urine production may contribute to oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia. Option: D: About 30% of affected neonates die shortly after birth due to respiratory insufficiency.

Extraedge:

Individuals withPKD2 develop renal failure approximately 15 years later than those with PKD1 Mutation Polycystic kidney disease may increase the risk of developing cancer of the liver, colon, and kidney (according to the study published in Lancet Oncology 19 Aug 2016) The most common extrarenal manifestation of PCKD is Polycystic liver disease.

questions.text: Tuberous sclerosis, also known as tuberous sclerosis complex, is a rare genetic condition that causes mainly non-cancerous (benign) tumors to develop in different parts of the body. The tumors most often affect the brain, skin, kidneys, heart, eyes, and lungs. Which of the following kidney disorders is associated with tuberous sclerosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Renal cell carcinoma

options.label: B
options.text: Renal angiomyolipoma

options.label: C
options.text: Kidney cysts

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Kidney cysts are a frequent feature of this condition, as are two other abnormalities of kidney growth, renal cell carcinoma, and renal angiomyolipoma.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A: Kidney cysts are a frequent feature of this condition. Option: B: The most common kidney finding in TS is the presence of angiomyolipomas. Option: C: In contrast to ADPKD, there is a clearly increased risk of renal cell carcinoma in TS patients. Regular periodic imaging is recommended in TS patients with kidney involvement to screen for the development of renal cell carcinoma.

questions.text: Medullary cystic kidney disease is caused by changes in the MUC1 gene. This gene provides instructions for making a protein called mucin 1. Changes in the gene lead to the production of an altered mucin protein. All of the following are true about Medullary cystic kidney disease EXCEPT?

options.label: A
options.text: MCKD I exhibit slowly progressive CKD in adulthood

options.label: B
options.text: Occasional renal cysts are seen on ultrasound examination

options.label: C
options.text: Disease recurs in transplanted kidneys

options.label: D
options.text: Kidney histology shows tubulointerstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy

questions.correct_answer: C. Disease recurs in transplanted kidneys
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Disease recurs in transplanted kidneys Disease does not recur in transplanted kidneys.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A: Clinically, patients with MCKD I exhibit slowly progressive CKD in adulthood, with only minimal amounts of increased urine protein. Option: B: Occasional renal cysts seen on ultrasound examination. Option: C: True.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presented with hematuria and flank pain. BP was found to be 170/110mmHg. The image of USG's abdomen is shown below. What is the mode of inheritance of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Autosomal-codominant

options.label: B
options.text: Autosomal dominant

options.label: C
options.text: Autosomal recessive

options.label: D
options.text: X-linked dominant

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Autosomal dominant The USG shows kidney with multiple cysts suggesting ADPKD as the diagnosis ADPKD Common Clinical Features:- Prevalence : 1:1000, Genes on chromosomes 16 (PKD1) and 4 (PKD2). Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) Flank pain and vague abdominal discomfort Acute loin pain or renal colic due to hemorrhage into the cysts. Hypertension may appear after the age of 20 years . complications Nocturia, hematuria, and urinary infection appear in the third or fourth decade. Pg. 1852 CRF can occur but with enlarged kidney size. Nephrolithiasis commonly due to uric acid calcium oxalate may be there. More than 50% of stones are due to uric acid. The remainder is due to oxalate Cysts may be there in the liver, pancreas, and spleen. Cysts are uncommon in the lungs . Liver cysts are the most common extrarenal complication of ADPKD. Intracranial (berry) aneurysms also may be present which can cause SAH. Azotemia is usually progressive. Colonic diverticula & abdominal wall hernia is common in ADPKD. Diagnosis is by ultrasound. Treatment :- Treating BP is important to prevent cardiovascular complications and SAH. Treat infections, dialysis, or transplantation for ESRF, genetic counseling. Pain may be helped by laparoscopic cyst removal or nephrectomy.

Highyeild:

Markers of poor prognosis Black males Diagnosis<30 years Hematuria HTN<35 years PKD1 truncating Mutations Kidney and Cyst volume on MRI are the strongest risk factor for renal function decline

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: C - Autosomal Recessive PKD presents in infants or a child, so this is not possible in this case. Option: A - not possible in cystic disease of the kidney.

Extraedge:

Treating BP is important to prevent cardiovascular complications and SAH. Treat infections, dialysis, or transplantation for ESRF, genetic counseling. Pain may be helped by laparoscopic cyst removal or nephrectomy.

questions.text: Medullary cystic kidney disease type 1 (MCKD1) is an inherited condition that affects the kidneys. It leads to scarring (fibrosis) and impaired function of the kidneys, usually beginning in adulthood. The kidneys filter fluid and waste products from the body - all are true regarding this condition except?

options.label: A
options.text: X linked in inheritance

options.label: B
options.text: MCKD type 1 patient do not have elevated uric acid levels

options.label: C
options.text: Kidney histology shows tubulointerstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy

options.label: D
options.text: Disease does not recur after transplantation

questions.explanation:
Solution:

X linked in inheritance Medullary cystic disease:- It manifests with polyuria, acidosis, and salt wasting, which precedes slowly progressive renal failure. Cysts are in the medulla Autosomal dominant Most patients with MCKD2 and the genetically related familial juvenile hyperuricemic nephropathy also have severe hyperuricemia and precocious onset of gout . MCKD1 does have hyperuricemia Diagnosis : a. Ultrasound, b. CT (more sensitive) Treatment: Supportive, Transplant(does not recur post-transplant)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option C - Histology shows fibrosis and atrophy - Option D - Disease does not recur after transplantation - this is a true statement.

questions.text: A Patient, 42 years old, was characterized by the progressive bilateral formation of renal cysts. Focal renal cysts were detected. The patient is complaining of flank pain often. All of the following are true except?

options.label: A
options.text: No specific treatment to prevent cyst growth

options.label: B
options.text: Antibiotics are preferred for cyst infection

options.label: C
options.text: Surgical decompression of cyst may be necessary

options.label: D
options.text: Rigorous control of blood pressure equals greater clinical benefit

questions.correct_answer: D. Rigorous control of blood pressure equals greater clinical benefit
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rigorous control of blood pressure equals greater clinical benefit This is a classic case of ADPDK. ADPDK is characterized by the progressive formation of epithelial-lined cysts in the kidney. Focal renal cysts are typically detected in affected subjects aged < 30 years. Hundreds to thousands of cysts are usually present in the kidneys of most patients in the fifth decade Rigorous control of blood pressure equals great clinical benefit This option is false The clinical history of the patient points towards autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease There is no specific treatment to prevent cyst growth or the decline of the renal function However blood pressure control to a target of 140/90 mmHg is recommended, as many of the patient present to opd with difficult to control hypertension but rigorous control of blood pressure does not equal greater clinical benefits maintaining a target systolic blood pressure to 110 mmHg in patients with moderate or advance disease might actually increase the risk of renal disease progression by reducing renal blood flow Hence rigorous control is not beneficial

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. No specific treatment to prevent cyst growth This option is true because there is no treatment approved for the control of cyst Symptomatic treatment is required in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease Option: B. Antibiotics are preferred for cyst infection Lipid soluble antibodies are preferred for cyst infection because most renal cysts are connected to glomerular filtration and antibiotics that are capable of penetrating this, are likely to be more effective. Option: C. Surgical decompression of cyst necessary Occasionally surgical decompression of cyst may be necessary Because the cyst can cause a lot of complications More than half of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease patients eventually required peritoneal dialysis, hemodialysis, or kidney transplantation

questions.text: A Patient, 43 years old, is having multiple cysts. The cysts are large growths in the nervous system, eyes, heart, lungs, liver, and skin. and there is an increased risk of development of renal cell carcinoma and renal angiomyolipoma. What is your diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

options.label: B
options.text: Von-Hippel-Lindau disease

options.label: C
options.text: Tuberous sclerosis

options.label: D
options.text: Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tuberous sclerosis Tuberous sclerosis Kidney cysts are a frequent feature of this condition, as are two other abnormalities of kidney growth,renal cell carcinoma, and renal angiomyolipomas. Ts is a syndrome affecting multiple organ systems. Other features of ts include benign growths in the nervous system, eyes, heart, lungs, liver, and skin. This patient is having multiple cysts And the cysts are large There is also the risk of developing renal cell carcinoma and angiomyolipoma. Hence the diagnosis of tuberous sclerosis is because the other options like autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease and autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease do not have the risk of developing renal cell carcinoma Other common symptoms of tuberous sclerosis include angiomyolipomas

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease This kidney disease also has multiple cysts but unlike tuberous sclerosis, there is no risk of developing renal cell carcinoma Option: B. Von- Hippel -Lindau disease Von- Hippel- Lindau disease is an inherited cancer syndrome with renal manifestation Kidney cysts and carcinoma affect the majority of VHL patients, but there is no separate risk of developing renal cell carcinoma Option: D. Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney In autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease, there is no risk of developing renal cell carcinoma as compared to tuberous sclerosis Here the hallmarks of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease are biliary dysgenesis due to a primary duct malformation with associated periportal fibrosis namely congenital hepatic fibrosis

questions.text: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is an inherited condition that causes small fluid-filled sacs called cysts to develop in the kidneys. Which of the following is the most common extrarenal complication associated with ADPKD ?

options.label: A
options.text: Liver cysts derived from the biliary epithelia

options.label: B
options.text: Pancreatic cysts

options.label: C
options.text: Hypertension

options.label: D
options.text: Subarachnoid hemorrhage

questions.correct_answer: A. Liver cysts derived from the biliary epithelia
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Liver cysts derived from the biliary epithelia Liver cysts derived from the biliary epithelia are the most common extrarenal complication.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B: Less common. Option: C: Hypertension is common, and typically occurs before any reduction in glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Hypertension is a risk factor for both cardiovascular and kidney disease progression in ADPKD. Option: D: Intracranial aneurysm (ICA) occurs four to five times more frequently in APDKD patients than that seen in the general population and causes high mortality.

Extraedge:

The major extrarenal complications of ADPKD are: Cerebral aneurysms Hepatic and pancreatic cysts Cardiac valve disease Colonic diverticula Abdominal wall and inguinal hernia Seminal vesicle cysts
